label: Food & Drink

description: Panya パン屋, For the last weekend of the festival, Swimsuit is transforming into its very own Japanese-inspired panya (bakery). At its tucked away Lombard Lane location you’ll be able to browse sweet treats, bread and onigiri created by Swimsuit head chef and Wellington On a Plate 2024 Next Gen winner, Aoife Gallagher-Forbes. Alongside these bakery delights there will be unique matcha drinks,and slow coffee (pour over) roasted by Swimsuit besties Coffee Supreme. Come enjoy the vibes all weekend!
label: Food & Drink

description: Create Your Own Coffee Blend, Join Mojo's team of coffee experts for this hands-on specialty coffee tasting and blending workshop at their iconic roastery on Wellington's waterfront. Experts will showcase the world's flavours through single-origin coffees and help you create your own custom blend to take home. Learn about the farmers Mojo work with, different coffee growing regions and why each coffee is so unique. Hosted by Mojo's highly experienced coffee specialists, their head roaster will also give you an up-close demonstration of the roasting process and explain what it takes to make the perfect blend. Drinks and nibbles provided.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Makers and Shakers, Makers and Shakers is back for 2025. Indulge in three one-of-a-kind love potions, each masterfully crafted by the talented team at Cuckoo Emporium and served in a unique ceramic vessel. These beautiful, handmade pieces come from the skilled local potters of the Wellington Potters Association. As you sip and savour your delicious concoctions, listen to the shakers tell their love stories behind their potions and the makers speak the sonnets of their creations. Your ticket includes three alcoholic cocktails, light snacks and three bespoke ceramic pieces to take home.
 
 (*Pottery shown are the vessels from the 2024 event and will be different this year)
label: Food & Drink

description:
JETAA Wellington - Brewkaiwa August @ The Welsh Dragon, We will be having our August Brewkaiwa at The Welsh Dragon, a cosy and quirky pub nestled in the heart of the city. With its warm atmosphere, distinctive character, and range of drinks on offer, it’s the perfect spot to relax, chat, and connect.
Brewkaiwa is JETAA’s monthly casual meetup for anyone with any connection to Japan.
We’re a diverse group of people who have studied, worked, or lived in Japan or have been invited along by someone who has.
Come join us for a brew and stay for the kaiwa! Bring your friends!
***Japanese or alcohol consumption NOT REQUIRED!***
Brewkaiwaとは
一杯いかがですか？
JETAAがウェリントンで親睦会を開催するとどうなるのか？その結果、BREWKAIWA！
2020年に始まった、ブリューカイワは、ウェリントンの様々なバーで毎月開催されている飲み会です。大人気の国際交流グルップです！！！ 日本で働いたり、住んだり、旅行したことのある人達に人気のあるイベントです！！！お酒を飲んで、友達を出来、素敵なごちそうを食べ、おまけに異文化を知られます！
日本語が話せる外国人も良く参加しているので、日本語しか話せなくても全然大丈夫です！
是非来てください！
label: Food & Drink

description: Breakfast Club, For one morning only – Loosie’s Superette is opening for breakfast, serving a comfort-filled menu with banging tunes and endless caffeine. Think trayfuls of fluffy pancakes, bacon and egg muffins, crispy hash browns drowned in maple syrup, and bottomless drip coffee to keep things rolling. Add a cheeky mimosa or two, and you’ve got the perfect start to your weekend. Whether you’re with your brunch crew, shaking off a hangover, or chasing the crispy bits, this is a morning made for indulgence. It’s all about good food, loud laughs, and that first sip of something strong with your best mates by your side. No rules, no rush - just tunes pumping, trays piling up, and that warm, familiar feeling of a proper brunch done right.
label: Food & Drink

description: Winemaker's Long Lunch, Sip, savour and socialise at Noble Rot's legendary Long Lunch. Fresh from this year’s prestigious Pinot Noir conference held in Christchurch in February, Noble Rot are so excited to host some of New Zealand's finest winemakers as Central Otago meets North Canterbury. Enjoy some special treats from the winemaker's own cellars as you while away the afternoon with with three generous courses served sharing style. Is there a better way to spend a Sunday afternoon?
label: Food & Drink

description:
We 💛 Mac 'n' Cheese, A feast with purpose, where every bowl makes a difference.
Celebrate the final day of Visa Wellington On a Plate and the end of winter with the ultimate comfort food: mac 'n' cheese, served all day long.

Two of Wellington’s legendary food rescue and community dining champions, Everybody Eats and Kaibosh, are joining forces to serve piping hot mac 'n' cheese, raising funds to help feed the community. As official charity partners of the festival, they are turning comfort food into real impact.

For just $10, each bowl will help fund a three-course meal for someone in need through Everybody Eats or provide a day’s worth of food for a family via Kaibosh.

Customise your mac with a range of toppings and flavours, all made from rescued food, showcasing just how delicious food recovery can be. In the lead-up to the event, Everybody Eats and Kaibosh will be calling on their social media followers to share their favourite mac 'n' cheese combos, with the top picks featured on the day.

Diners can enjoy their meal seated in the Everybody Eats restaurant or opt for takeaway to share with the whānau or flat.

The goal is to serve 2,000 bowls and fund 2,000 meals for the community. Join the celebration, enjoy incredible kai and help make a real difference.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Love Language, Calling budding poets and hopeless romantics - this is your opportunity to share your love of language, with a food and poetry degustation. 
This four-course dinner is a physical manifestation of love and an ode to food. Join Simon Sweetman, Wellington writer, critic, musician and poet, as he reads some of his own poetry, and yours too if you're feeling game. Chefs Tim and Aaron Banks will lovingly create a four-course dinner with ingredients locally sourced and lovingly produced by small scale sustainable farmers... and perhaps they will read their own poems too. 
If you're feeling poetic bring along your own poem specially crafted around this year's festival theme 'Food is Love'. It can be as long or short as you like, as happy or sad, comical or tragic, Keats or Bukowski. Spot prizes for various categories including 'Most Related to the Theme' and 'Most Obviously Foodie' poems. Includes four courses, and a welcome glass of bubbles on arrival.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Paediatrics: Daytime Mobility & Function + Practical Workshop (Wellington), Paediatric Academy Wellington - Venue to be announced
_____________________________________________________________________________________________
Overview:
Join us for an engaging and interactive session focused on paediatric Assistive Technology (AT) and safe car seat solutions! We’ll explore prescribing AT for sitting, standing, stepping, and mobility—blending clinical theory with real-world insights on equipment choices.
Engage in a hands-on practical session to test techniques, plus learn how to collaborate with parents, caregivers, and kids for practical, daily-use solutions, including safe transportation. Don’t miss this chance to boost your skills and confidence!
Learning Objectives
Identify and describe different types of paediatric Assistive Technology (AT) equipment
Explain the clinical rationale behind equipment prescription
Enhance collaboration with families and caregivers
Assess the functional needs of children and recommend suitable AT solutions
About our Presentor:
Jamie's Bio:
BSc Physiotheraop, Paediatric Product Education - Medifab
Jamie Cockle is a trained physiotherapist and Medifab's Paediatric Clinical Educator and Seating and Positioning Specialist. With a passion for empowering therapists, product specialists, and families, Jamie provides expert training on Medifab’s paediatric equipment, ensuring practical knowledge that can be applied every day to optimise children’s health and happiness.
Jamie’s career began as a Paediatric Physiotherapist at Noah’s Ark Children’s Hospital in Cardiff, followed by a role at Bristol Royal Hospital for Children. It was in these settings that he developed his expertise in paediatric equipment, particularly for children with neurological conditions. He is driven by the belief that every child should have access to the right support, regardless of their abilities or diagnosis..
label: Health & Wellness

description:
It's in the Ballot - TDC – Eketahuna Community Board - In-studio, Contestants of 'It's in the Bag' become political candidates in 'It's in the Ballot' Meet the Candidates.
Candidates choose a numbered box which has a question that has been submitted online by voters before the show.
It’s in the Ballot” is a community-led awareness and participation initiative. We aim to increase voter interest in the general and council elections nationally.
By using broadcasting and web-based technologies to deliver in-studio; online on Facebook, YouTube and Twitch; and edited as YouTube videos we aim to enable voters to make informed voting decisions.
This means you can send the weblink of the YouTube Video of your electorate show to your friends and whanau to encourage them to watch the show before they cast their votes.
Voting papers are sent to voters on Tuesday 9th September 2025 and must be delivered into a voting dropbox by 12pm Saturday 11th October 2025
label: Government & Politics

description:
It's in the Ballot - Tararua District Council – South Ward -In-studio, Contestants of 'It's in the Bag' become political candidates in 'It's in the Ballot' Meet the Candidates.
Candidates choose a numbered box which has a question that has been submitted online by voters before the show.

description:
Glow in the Dark Paint Party: Aurora Lake Scene, Ultra Violet lights and neon nights. Prepare to experience Paintvine like you’ve never experienced it before - in the dark!

Paintvine After Dark is New Zealand’s first glow in the dark paint party!

Grab a drink in one hand, a brush in the other and get your creative juices flowing and your brush strokes going with ultra-violet lights, glow in the dark paint and nothing but laughs all night long!

Drinks: No drinks are included in the ticket price, but drinks are available for purchase.

Food: A delicious menu will be available to purchase throughout the event.

What is Paintvine?
It’s a fun social painting class where our artists will run you through step-by-step instructions on how to create your very own masterpiece in a fun and relaxed bar setting. Perfect for dates, catching up with mates or for meeting new friends!

We provide all the materials you need (high-quality canvas, neon acrylic paint, brushes). All you need to bring is your creative spirit (or find some at the bottom of a glass). All our events are in licensed venues, so you can purchase drinks to sip as you create! At the end of the night you will leave with your own fluro painting ready to hang up on your wall.

For tickets, future events, FAQs and more info head to the Paintvine website ⇒ paintvine.co.nz

description:
A free workshop for the General Public: Dying to Know about Dying Matters?, Please note, this is a FREE workshop availble to the public and is not designed for health professionals to attend.
Many people find it difficult to talk about dying, yet dying is an important stage of life and is inevitable.
We plan for the birth of a child, yet when it comes to the end of life, we don’t often want to think , or talk about it.
Come along to our workshop and find out more about dying matters, how an Advance Care Planning (ACP)can benefit you and your family/whānau and what to expect at the end of life.
Having a plan outlines our care preferences for the future. Having an Advance Care Plan (ACP) that aligns with our beliefs and values, is a gift that we can give to our family / whānau.
We will explore:
Why is it hard to talk about death and dying?
What to expect when someone is dying
Supports available
Advance care planning processes
Date: Friday 5 September 2025
Time: 9.00 am - 12.30 pm
Presenters: Mary Ann Hardcastle Advance Care Plannining Facilitator & Chris Dunn Clinical Nurse Educator Nelson Tasman Hospice
Cost: Free
Limited attendees: Registration is essential
Who can attend?: General Public (This workshop is not designed for Health Professionals)
Venue: Nelson Tasman Hospice, 331 Suffolk Road, Stoke, Nelson
label: Health & Wellness

description:
2025 Taiwan Update Lectures, Taiwan’s Multidimensional Energy Security Challenges
Professor Chyungly Lee
A stable and reliable energy supply is essential for a nation’s economic growth and development. In selecting fuel sources, nowadays almost all countries have taken climate change into account, adopted sensible clean energy transition plans, and designed a schedule to meet the goal of Net Zero. While pursuing a 3-E (energy-economic-environmental) balanced energy supply strategy, Taiwan, lacking indigenous resources, faces unique challenges of supply disruptions from over dependence on energy imports and possible blockade, quarantine, or invasion from Beijing. Any disruption of power supply or surge of energy costs could not only threaten Taiwan’s competitive edge in the global high-tech market but also undermine Taiwan’s internal stability and the nation’s survival. In this talk, Dr. Chyungly Lee will first present fact sheets on Taiwan’s energy status, summarize Taiwan’s current energy strategy, and then discuss dilemmas and vulnerabilities that Taiwan might face in the next few years.
What does Taiwan’s two-level politics tell us?
Professor Alex Tan
This presentation examines Taiwan as a critical case study for understanding the evolving challenges to democracy in the 21st century. Arguing that Taiwan serves as a “canary in the coalmine,” the analysis highlights how the island’s early and persistent political polarization—rooted in identity politics and the legacies of authoritarian rule—prefigures trends now visible in established democracies worldwide. The research explores how deep divisions between the Kuomintang (KMT) and Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), reinforced by institutional and social factors, have led to legislative gridlock, declining trust in political institutions, and a “democratic ceiling” that constrains further democratic development. Taiwan’s precarious geopolitical position, facing constant pressure from the People’s Republic of China, intensifies the dilemma of balancing national security with the protection of civil liberties. The presentation analyzes Taiwan’s innovative responses to disinformation, foreign interference, and public health crises, illustrating both the resilience and fragility of democratic systems under external and internal stress.
Gaming Taiwan: Indigenous Epistemologies in Play
Associate Professor Chia-rong Wu
This research explores how Indigenous knowledge systems in Taiwan are being revitalized through video games. Far from mere entertainment, these games draw on tribal traditions, ancestral stories, and deep connections to the land to create meaningful digital experiences. By blending oral storytelling with interactive gameplay, Taiwanese Indigenous game developers are preserving cultural memory while challenging colonial legacies. Titles like Princess Baleng, Tayal, VuVu, and Gadvia show how games can empower communities and pass down wisdom to younger generations in innovative and engaging ways. Gamers not only play a game but also immerse themselves in digital environments shaped by Indigenous perspectives and values. This study encourages all engaged audiences, including educators and students, to consider video games as powerful tools for cultural resurgence and learning. Focusing on Indigenous Taiwan, it highlights how digital games integrate historical consciousness and interactivity to reimagine the past and future of the island.

description:
Film screening: GAGA, Gaga《哈勇家》(2022)
Directed by Laha Mebow 112 mins, Mandarin/Atayal/Taiwanese, English subtitles
Among the Atayal indigenous people of Taiwan, gaga is the traditional law and custom, the way of living with the land and organising society, the source of values. When Hayung, the patriarch of an Atayal family, and the senior knowledge-keeper, dies, his oldest son Payang decides to run for election as head of the local district. The film Gaga follows this election, in its raw democratic, and occasionally corrupt, form and the ways – sometimes serious, sometimes hilarious – that it affects the extended family. A groundbreaking film, Gaga is mostly in Atayal language and presents the life and social interactions of these contemporary indigenous Taiwanese people unsentimentally, with humour, with compassion, and with the sharp eye of a brilliant film-maker.
Gaga won Best Director and Best Supporting Actress at the 59th Taipei Golden Horse Film Festival in 2022. Beyond Taiwan, it won the Best Director at the 2022 Singapore International Film Festival - Asian Feature Competition and has been screened at film festivals in Hawaii, Los Angeles, Melbourne, Auckland and New York.
Q&A with Film Director Laha Mebow
We are delighted that Film Director Laha Mebow, Taiwan's first indigenous female director, will be attending the screening and take part in Q&A afterwards.
Laha Mebow is the first female director from Taiwan to win Best Director at the Golden Horse Awards, the most prestigious film award in the Chinese-speaking world. An Indigenous filmmaker of the Tayal people, she is also the first Indigenous woman in Taiwan to direct a narrative feature. Her films explore spiritual inheritance, family trauma, and Indigenous identity through a deeply personal yet cinematic lens.
She has directed three feature films. Finding Sayun (2011) reimagines a colonial-era legend from an Indigenous perspective. Lokah Laqi! (2016), a coming-of-age tale of three Indigenous boys, was selected as Taiwan’s official submission for Best Foreign Language Film at the Academy Awards. Her third feature, Gaga (2022), won Best Film at the Singapore International Film Festival and delves into generational shifts and cultural survival within an Indigenous family.
Laha’s body of work continues to break new ground for Indigenous representation in Asian cinema. Her unique voice bridges traditional storytelling and contemporary filmmaking, making her one of the most important and anticipated directors from Taiwan today.
label: Film & Media

description:
French Film Screening - Chien de la Casse, 🎬 Join us for a screening of Chien de la casse (Junkyard Dog) - a gritty and quietly powerful French drama exploring friendship, masculinity, and emotional repression in a small town in France.
The plot 👉 In a sleepy village in the South of France, Dog and Mirales have been inseparable since childhood. Their bond is strong but also marked by teasing and power games - until a new arrival, Elsa, disrupts the dynamic. As Dog starts to drift toward this budding romance, Mirales is left grappling with jealousy, vulnerability, and the fear of being left behind.
The trailer 👉 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tCv83D3CQOY
Chien de la casse is a nuanced and touching debut feature by Jean-Baptiste Durand - a subtle portrait of male friendship, emotional fragility, and the unspoken tensions of rural life.
This film is rated R13 – Restricted to persons 13 years and over (Violence, offensive language, drug use & sex scenes).
📅 Friday, 05 September 2025 - 6pm
📍 Alliance Française, 78 Victoria Street, Wellington
🎥 French VO with English Subtitles
🎟️ Free entry, Koha donation
label: Film & Media

Grab your mates and discover the best bars in Pōneke Wellington on the self-guided Urban Cocktail Trail! Whether you're a cocktail lover, or just up for a fun afternoon out, this trail is all about good drinks and great vibes!

Kick things off with a bite at your starting venue, then make your way around using your cocktail vouchers. Where you go and what you sip is totally up to you!

Tickets will fly, so lock yours in and get ready for an afternoon of flavour and fun!

FAQs

Parking is available at the venue, at a cost of $10. Please note parking is card payment only (entry to the Show is card or cash).
2. What is the best time to attend?
Peak visitor times are normally between 11am - 2pm so the crowds are less outside of these times.

A printed ticket or showing the barcode on your phone to the entry staff is required.

description:
Taiwan’s Economic Statecraft and the future of Liberal International Order, Abstract
Over the last decade, China has punished countries that undermine its territorial claims and foreign policy goals with measures such as restricting trade, encouraging popular boycotts, and cutting off tourism. These coercive measures have caused significant economic damage to U.S. partners such as Japan, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Australia. This talk focuses on Taiwan’s response to China’s economic sanctions, highlighting the agency of medium-sized countries in the shadow of a great power.
The second part of this presentation will propose a common understanding of the liberal international order in which state and non-state actors follow rules, norms, and legal procedures in conducting international affairs. This rule-based practice is an essential part of the Asian regional order. If Taiwan were integrated into the multilateral institutions in Asia, the chance of conflict would be greatly reduced. The future of Taiwan also depends on the resilience of the liberal international order and other middle-power states in the Asia Pacific.
Bio
Christina Lai is an Associate Research Fellow in the Institute of Political Science at Academia Sinica, Taiwan. Dr. Lai received her Ph.D. in Government from Georgetown University. In 2015-2016, she was a post-doctoral fellow in China and the World Program at Princeton University. She is interested in U.S.-China-Taiwan Relations, Chinese Foreign Policy, East Asian politics, and Qualitative Research Methods. Her works have appeared in the Politics, International Politics, Political Science, PS: Political Science & Politics, Journal of Contemporary China, Pacific Review, and Asian Security.
label: Government & Politics

description:
The Liberal International Order as a Core-Periphery Order: An Alternative History with Multiple Deep Contestations, I offer an alternative macrohistory of the Liberal International Order (LIO) that was explicitly designed to perpetuate Western dominance and American hegemony. The LIO is better understood as a core-periphery order because inequality between the Western-core and the ‘Restern’-periphery was constitutive of it. (Re-)Imperialism—not just liberalism—remained a central ordering mechanism well after 1945. I show the two-way deep contestations between the liberal and anticolonial ordering projects, especially at the 1955 Bandung Conference. Contra the post-LIO pessimism of disorder/chaos, I argue that the normative agency of the Southeast Asian states informed by the legacy of Bandung is heralding a multiplex, multi-regional world order. As the declining inequality between the West and Asia transforms the core-periphery LIO, the emergent decentered world order will lack a core, whether Western/liberal or Asian. This deep transformation should be welcomed, not deeply contested, although coexistence and global integration require embracing deep pluralism, not liberalism.
Manjeet S. Pardesi is Associate Professor of International Relations in the Political Science and International Relations Programme, and Asia Research Fellow at the Centre for Strategic Studies at Victoria University of Wellington. His research interests include World Orders and World/Global History, Great Power Politics, Asian security, and the Sino-Indian rivalry. His most recent book, Divergent Worlds: What the Ancient Mediterranean and Indian Ocean Can Tell Us About the Future of International Order (co-authored with Amitav Acharya) was published by Yale University Press in 2025.
label: Government & Politics

description:
Draw It Out - Teens block course, A fun and deep way for teens (11-17 year olds) to learn to process their feelings.
Theme: Listening to your inner voice
Learn how to listen to your feelings and find guidance from within, using a gentle powerful tool called Interactive Drawing Therapy.
Teenage years can often be filled with external influences, making it hard to listen to our own inner voice for guidance. This 4-session block course teaches teens how to use drawing to process hard feelings and access their own inner resources, which can be used at home as visual journaling.
Dates
This block course consists of 4 workshops:
4.15pm-5.30pm
Tuesday 19th August - Metaphors for feelings
Tuesday 26th August - Uncovering needs
Tuesday 2nd September - Unlocking self-compassion
Monday 8th September - Curiosity in direction
Cost
$184 total ($46 per session)
Included in each session
You will be guided by Lara Phillips, a trained creative facilitator in Interactive Drawing Therapy, through drawing prompts (similar to a guided meditation or journaling) to draw out where you are at and draw out your own inner guidance. No art skills are needed, more simple mark making.
This gentle yet powerful tool uses drawing and writing as a way to access your subconscious and to listen to your heart rather than your head for guidance. A tool often used in therapy, it is made accessible for self-care and community wellness through these workshops.
About Lara Phillips
Lara Phillips is a creative facilitator trained in Interactive Drawing Therapy. With a 20 year career in creative copywriting in design and communication, she shares drawing and writing as a mode for wellness and self-care, to promote preventative and proactive mental health measures through creativity.
“We all have the wisdom within to help ourselves, if given the space.”
For more workshops or to book individual sessions visit www.drawitout.co.nz

Liability disclaimer
Draw It Out offers creativity for wellbeing. It is not intended as therapy nor does it replace counselling, therapy, or any other medical or clinical professional help. Participants are guided to draw out where they are at, whilst drawing out their own inner resources for support and guidance.
Participants understand it is their own responsibility to manage their mental and physical health during sessions, to opt in and out of activities as they see fit, and make the facilitator aware if further support is required.

description:
Peace Over Panic: Rewiring the Anxious Mind, Peace Over Panic: Rewiring the Anxious Mind
Tuesday Wellbeing Seminars
How do we respond when the mind spirals, when uncertainty clouds our judgement, or when we find ourselves at a personal breaking point? This workshop draws from ancient and time-tested wisdom found in yoga philosophy — especially the Bhagavad Gita — to explore how anxiety and inner conflict can become turning points for insight and conscious action.
Rather than avoiding or suppressing discomfort, the Gita offers a way to meet it — with clarity, honesty, and meaningful direction. Through a blend of philosophical reflection and grounded tools, we’ll explore how to steady the mind and reconnect with deeper purpose in the face of pressure or doubt.


Meet your host, Sivananda
Sivananda’s background is in both science and music, holding a Master's Degree in Data Science, a Bachelor of Science in Physics and a long history of playing and performing on the double bass. His passion for philosophy, music, good food and community attracted him to the bhakti lifestyle. Having studied and practiced the science of the ‘self’ for six years now, he thrives on drawing insights from contemporary science and combining it with yoga wisdom to encourage others to explore new perspectives.
6.15pm Tuesday 19th August
End the session on a high note with a delicious plant-based dinner, dessert, and good conversation.
Tickets available here~ bit.ly/eventTickets
Bhakti Lounge 1/175 Vivian Street, Te Aro, Wellington. http://www.bhaktilounge.org.nz

description:
Dine with a Doc - The power of plant-based nutrition and lifestyle interventions, Doctors For Nutrition and MTM Community Project invite you to an evening of inspiration, education, and connection at our next ‘Dine with a Doc’ dinner.
Join us for a presentation on ‘The Power of Plant-Based Nutrition and Lifestyle Interventions for Preventing Chronic Disease’—an event designed to empower everyone from healthcare professionals to health-conscious community members. You will also be the first to hear about the new MTM Community Project, and about their mission. 
When: 6:30pm – 9:30pm, Tuesday, 19th August 2025
Where: Gear Homestead, 1 Okowai Road, Aotea, Wellington
Price: $50 (includes dinner and non-alcoholic beverage)
At this event, Dr Heleen Haitjema will take you on a journey through the clinical benefits of whole food, plant-based (WFPB) nutrition. Through easy-to-understand explanations of key concepts - such as endothelial dysfunction, intramyocellular lipid accumulation, and calorie density - you’ll discover how WFPB eating can dramatically improve health outcomes and transform lives. 
After the presentation, join us for a panel discussion and a Q&A session with Dr Haitjema and Dr Luke Wilson. 
The evening continues with a plant-based dinner curated by the chefs from MTM Community Project, served in the elegant setting of Gear Homestead. Enjoy the opportunity to connect and network with leading dietitians, specialists, GPs, and passionate members of New Zealand’s plant-based community.
Buy your tickets now; spaces are strictly limited!
Sponsored by: Little City Kombucha

description:
Empathic Boundaries: Saying No Without Guilt, Empathic Boundaries: Saying No Without Guilt
If you hear rejection when someone says "no" to you, or if you struggle to say "no" even when you want to - this workshop is for you.
Plus there is an amazing plant-based dinner & dessert included in your ticket! Stay back to continue the connects over a nourishing meal.


In this workshop based on Nonviolent Communication (NVC) you will discover how to listen to feelings and needs that sit behind the "no" and how to connect to what truly matters to yourself and others. You will get to know some foundational tools of NVC, and practice on examples from real life. This session is interactive, and you will walk away with some understanding of NVC processes and materials to practice in your own time.


You will discover:
what stops you from saying "no" when you really want to
how to connect to what matters (to you and others) and find the needs behind the "no"
how to listen for needs, rather than look for conflict


Meet Helen & Anna, your hosts
Anna Banaś and Helen Williams are passionate, down-to-earth facilitators who bring warmth, depth, and a wealth of experience to their work in Nonviolent Communication (NVC). Anna is undertaking certification as an NVC trainer, a sociolinguist, and skilled group facilitator who has spent nearly 20 years supporting families, organisations, and communities to communicate with more clarity and compassion. Helen brings a rich blend of experience as a mindfulness teacher, mediator, coach, and yoga practitioner. Together, Anna and Helen create a safe, engaging, and supportive space where learning feels both empowering and nourishing. Whether you’re completely new to NVC or looking to deepen your practice, you’ll be in very good hands.

Meet your hosts:

description:
Breathwork: A Gentle Reset, Breathwork: A Gentle Reset
Take a pause from the noise of daily life.
This breathwork journey begins with gentle movement to awaken the body and open the breath. Through slow, mindful stretches, we begin softening tension and grounding into the present.
You’ll then be guided through two styles of breathwork — each offering a unique pathway inward. There’s no pressure or expectation, just the freedom to explore what feels right for you:
A dynamic, connected breath for those who wish to build energy, move emotion, or break through internal blockages
A slow, rhythmic breath for those seeking stillness, calm, and deeper grounding
Both approaches invite a sense of spaciousness — physically, mentally, and emotionally — while supporting nervous system balance and inner clarity.
To gently close the session, we’ll move into a quiet, nurturing meditation to support integration and leave you feeling steady, clear, and connected.
Afterwards, stay and enjoy a nourishing plant-based dinner and dessert, lovingly prepared to complement the experience — because healing is also about how we feed and care for ourselves.
Why Breathwork?
Breathwork has helped so many shift from a state of tension and overwhelm into a place of ease, clarity, and resilience — often after just one session. It’s a simple, powerful practice that reconnects you to your body, your breath, and your inner stillness.
You’ll leave feeling more grounded, more present, and more like yourself again.
Meet Karla, your host
Karla is a breathwork and trauma-somatic facilitator based in Aotearoa (New Zealand), originally from Malta. With over a decade of experience in Reiki and three years facilitating trauma-informed, science-based breathwork, Karla combines holistic tools, meditation, and conscious breathing to support nervous system regulation and deep emotional healing. Her offerings help release stored trauma, reduce stress and anxiety, and activate oxytocin—the “love hormone”—fostering connection, vitality, and a sense of wholeness. She currently holds regular classes, workshops, and transformative retreats that nurture the mind, body, and spirit.

description:
Habits mastery series: Buy Back Your Time, Habits mastery series: Buy Back Your Time
Tuesday Wellbeing Seminars
You don’t need more hours in the day — you just need to stop spending them on the wrong things.
You’re busy. I get it. There’s just no time for the things that you really want to do, right?
"Buy Back Your Time" is a 1-hour interactive workshop for anyone who wants to reclaim their time, energy, and focus — without burnout or hustle culture.
In this session, you'll learn:
Why time management is really attention management
How to shift from reacting to designing your days
Practical tools to create space for what actually matters
How to identify & eliminate your biggest time-wasters
You’ll walk away with a simple plan to buy back your time — and start investing it in your goals, your growth, and your life.
Meet your host, Nava
Nava’s natural interest in studying physics blossomed into metaphysics when she arrived in the land of the long white cloud. Originally from Germany, Nava was travelling on a quest to find purpose and answers to the mysteries of life. Did she find anything on this quest? Yes! After four exciting years of inquiry, practice, and being immersed in the wonders of bhakti yoga, she is still fully inspired by what she has discovered. Mesmerized by the depth and broad-mindedness that a yoga lifestyle offers, Nava is keen to share with you that wisdom and love, along with her experiences on the road of life. Nava is also an expert vegan chef who specializes in European cuisine and baking, and she is busy spreading that kind of love around Bhakti Lounge too!
6.15pm Tuesday 26th August
End the session on a high note with a delicious plant-based dinner, dessert, and good conversation.
Tickets available here~ bit.ly/eventTickets
Bhakti Lounge 1/175 Vivian Street, Te Aro, Wellington. http://www.bhaktilounge.org.nz
label: Health & Wellness

description:
Humans: Why & What To Do, Humans: Why & What To Do
Talk by Devamrita Swami + Plant-Based Dinner & Dessert
We’re the most connected generation in history — and somehow the loneliest.
We’ve built more technology than any civilisation before us — and still can’t solve our basic problems.
We talk endlessly about progress — while the planet burns and mental health plummets.
What if the trouble isn’t just what we’re doing… but that we’ve forgotten why we’re doing it?
In this bold, no-fluff talk, Devamrita Swami — a world-traveling monk, strategist, and social critic — unpacks the mess we’re in and asks the questions most of us avoid: Why are we here? And what should we actually be doing about it?
Afterwards, stick around for a plant-based dinner and dessert — fresh, colourful, and made to share. Grab a plate, grab a seat, and dive into real conversations with people who are curious, open-minded, and up for something different.
Meet Devamrita Swami, your host:
Devamrita Swami is an educator, author, and monk who has spent over forty years exploring and sharing the wisdom of bhakti-yoga. He brings ancient Vedic teachings to life, effortlessly navigating the latest research in archaeology, consciousness, ancient history, neuroscience, social science, and psychology. Author of Searching for Vedic India and Hiding in Unnatural Happiness, he combines philosophy with practical insights on happiness, wellbeing, and personal fulfillment. For anyone seeking to channel the human drive for fulfilment in a meaningful and sustainable way, Devamrita Swami offers clear, engaging, and indispensable wisdom.

description:
Men's Circle: Reclaiming Connection, Men's Circle: Reclaiming Connection
The Men’s Circle is a free, supportive gathering for men to connect, share openly, and grow together. Whether you're navigating life changes, seeking community, or simply wanting a space to be heard, you're welcome here.
Expect honest conversations and the kind of connection that’s rare but necessary. No pressure to speak—just your presence is enough. We follow a respectful, non-judgmental format that prioritizes safety, confidentiality, and authenticity.
Optional Plant-Based Dinner
Stay afterwards for a nourishing, plant-based dinner and dessert ($15). Sharing a meal is a powerful way to extend the connection beyond the circle. This gathering is not run for profit—Andre is simply passionate about creating spaces for genuine connection.
What to Expect in the Circle:
Gathering in Circle: We sit in a circle to foster a sense of unity and equality.
Centering In: A short meditation or silence helps us arrive and ground.
Talking Object: A shared object moves around—only the person holding it speaks.
Optional Sharing: Speak if you feel moved. You’re always welcome to pass.
Active Listening: No interruptions, advice, or feedback—just presence.
Confidentiality: What's shared in the circle, stays in the circle.
Our Shared Agreements:
Speak from the “I”: Share from your own experience, not on behalf of others.
No fixing or judging: This is not a space to solve, but to witness.
Be present: Share what’s alive for you right now.
Respect and trust: We uphold a culture of care, confidentiality, and non-judgment.
Meet Andre, your host
Andre has been immersed in men’s work since the age of 13, when he first experienced a rite of passage in Golden Bay. That formative experience sparked a lifelong connection to circle work, which he later deepened by returning as a mentor. Over the years, Andre has come to value the power of sitting in circle—of men coming together in honesty, vulnerability, and presence to witness and support one another. A multi-instrumental musician, poet, and pranayama (breathwork) facilitator, Andre also brings his passion for ecstatic dance, philosophy, and authentic connection into his offerings. He is deeply inspired by the question of what it means to be human—how we can more fully experience our aliveness, our depth, and reconnecting with the beauty of life together.

It’ll be a transcendent evening of Sacred Harmonic Sounds, where multi-instrumentalist Claudio Escutia will guide you through a deeply restorative sonic experience. Plus - there will be an amazing plant-based dinner & dessert included in your ticket!
Let the vibrations of Gongs, Crystal and Tibetan singing bowls, Native American flutes, and other ancient instruments wash over you—melting away tension, quieting the mind, and opening a doorway to inner stillness.
With Claudio’s masterful soundscapes, you’ll not only hear the music but feel it resonating through your body, inviting profound relaxation and a reconnection to your heart. No prior meditation or yoga experience is needed—just come as you are and let the sound carry you into a space of deep peace.

Born into a musical family in Mexico City, Claudio’s lifelong passion for sound has taken him across the globe—from studying jazz in Montreal to mastering Tibetan singing bowls in Kathmandu. In attending my classes, i trust that you are in a good health condition and that you know of no medical or other reason why you cannot or should not engage in active or passive exercise. description:
Bride Of The Year 2025, For 55 years, Wairarapa Bride of the Year has been a mainstay in the events calendar in the region. The event returns to the Wairarapa Events Centre for 2025, where brides who were married between 1 July and 30 June and were married in the Wairarapa, and/or have lived or are living in the Wairarapa, and/or whose spouse has lived in the Wairarapa, will get the chance to relive the magic of their big day, donning their gowns again, all while raising much needed funds for Te Awhina Plunket Wairarapa.

This event is unique in its focus on Wairarapa’s flourishing wedding industry. It is a great opportunity for couples planning their own weddings to look for inspiration from other local couples, for friends and families of brides to reminisce on the weddings. It is also an excellent opportunity to support Wairarapa Plunket and the service they provide to our community.

In 2024, the funds raised through Bride of the Year went towards purchasing equipment for use for Plunket rooms across Wairarapa along with purchase .

A ticket to Bride of the Year provides you with a night of glamour and celebration of love, all while supporting Wairarapa Plunket and the service they provide to our community.

description:
LIFE DRAWING MEETS YOGA!, Connect with your body and your creativity in this all-levels workshop that combines vinyasa yoga practice with a fun and interactive Life Drawing class!
The Life Drawing session is based on the teaching methods of Cecil Collins, a British artist whose non-academic approach to drawing challenges you to leave your inhibitions at the door and work freely from your creative centre...much like yoga!
“But I can’t draw!,” you say. Then even better! This approach is perfect for the artist and non-artist alike as it asks you to drop your expectations of what art should look like, inviting you to express the pose from within…just like we do in yoga.
Drinks & nibbles follow, along with a chance for kōrero and connection.
Guided by JoElle Gragilla from South Coast Studio in Island Bay, who studied Cecil’s methods in London and is an artist, art teacher and AWHI-trained yoga teacher. Co-facilitated by AWHI's Lachlan Broughton.

description:
Sika Sound Journey, This powerful experience is like a soundtrack that is crafted to go with your life.

Something between an ancient ceremony and a movie soundtrack.

Please bring a yoga mat, pillow and blanket. Be prepared to drop into a deep space.
Door sales will be available if there is space. Advanced booking is recommended.

Sika's Sound Journeys are truly unique. They are sonic explorations that feature didgeridoos, drums, flutes, voice and orchestral elements. A collection of foraged sounds from objects he has recorded in nature, add even more textures. Many of his sounds are completely unrecognisable and abstract. Immersed in this cocoon of abstract sound, we can find ourselves in the most surprising places in our mind. In this timeless realm, beyond the normal limitations of rational reality, anything is possible.

An epic adventure deep inside yourself.

Journey to worlds within worlds on incredible sound waves.

Sika creates a safe space to relax deeply and connect with our inner guidance. This Sound Journey begins and ends with a short guided visualisation.

There will be two journeys with an interval. Most people choose to lie down, so once again, please bring a yoga mat, pillow and blanket to get really comfortable.

A journal is also recommended.

description:
The Mind, Body, & Climate Change, The Mind, Body, & Climate Change 
Explore how young minds can drive change by understanding the links between climate change, well-being, and action.

Free kai. Big ideas. Good vibes.
Ready to connect the dots between your own well-being and the planet’s future? We’re talking real talk, fresh perspectives, and a whole lot of inspiration — without the boring lecture vibe.
Devamrita Swami — world-travelling monk, renowned strategist, social observer, and all-round thought-provoker — is back at Vic Uni. He’s spoken at universities all over the globe, and now he’s here to flip the way you see climate action and mental health.
And yes… free plant-based dinner is on us:
– Loaded nachos (salsa, taco ‘meat’, sour ‘cream’ & ‘cheese’)
– Strawberry & peanut butter milkshakes
– Caramel & chocolate donuts
Come for the food, stay for the conversation. Vibe with good humans, share some laughs, and leave with fresh ideas you’ll actually want to act on.
When: Tues 16 Sept, 5:45 pm
Where: Vic Uni, Kelburn Parade — MacLaurin Building MCLT103 (up the steps from the Hub). We’ll have people outside pointing you in the right direction. Lost? Text us: +64 20 4191 5046
Click ‘Get Tickets’ to save your seat (and your donut).

description:
Healing the Feminine & Masculine: A Ceremony of Heart & Dance, A sacred afternoon of cacao & heart sharing, embodied movement, and mutual honouring to heal the wounding and reconnect the masculine and feminine within and between us.
We’ll begin with a mixed-gender cacao heart share circle — a sacred, confidential space for Tāne and Wāhine to be vulnerable, seen, and heard.
Through ecstatic dance, we move and release energy together. A rich tapestry of tribal beats, global rhythms, and soul-stirring melodies.
We’ll close in a powerful honouring circle — women in the centre, men surrounding them with gratitude, then reversing, as we collectively tend to the wounded masculine–feminine connection with love and presence.

description:
Teaching Well - A supportive school for a well staff - Wellington (TWS2025/04), Growing attention to staff wellbeing has resulted in many workplace mental wellbeing initiatives. Nevertheless, the concept of staff wellbeing is rarely well-defined, with programs focusing on either work-related stressors or staff wellness approaches.

As part of a well school, it is just as essential to have a well staff as it is to a well student body. Don't miss out! Discover the key principles of wellbeing and build a sustainable, impactful plan for your staff.

Join this workshop tailored for schools & kura, exploring how to promote staff wellbeing in 2025. Learn the theory and practice of promoting wellbeing in staff!
From Remedial to Sustainable Action
Providing resources or assistance programmes to help staff manage job stress is a single element of an extensive staff wellbeing plan. Schools commonly start at the remedial end of the wellbeing continuum, creating welfare or wellness plans. Learning the differences between welfare, wellness, and wellbeing approaches, including their strengths and weaknesses, is important.

Meta-evaluations reveal that many workplace mental wellbeing programmes lack efficacy due to not addressing organisational and systemic factors that impact wellbeing. Effective staff wellbeing programmes must respond to staff needs and reflect the school's cultural values and character.
Utilizing collective impact, transformational change theory, and Te Whare Tapa Whā, we introduce a conceptual model outlining the eight pillars essential for a staff wellbeing plan. This model's strength lies in its specificity to different settings or occupations, necessitating an in-depth analysis of work nature, dynamics, and inter-relationships.
Based on insights from past workshops and participant feedback, this workshop now provides a comprehensive template for developing staff wellbeing plans.
This workshop does not offer a pre-packaged wellbeing programme. Research indicates that externally imposed wellbeing programmes have limited efficacy in schools. Effective staff wellbeing plans must be rooted in insights gained from reflective analysis and staff consultations. Notably, the consultation process itself is a key wellbeing activity.
Take the opportunity to hear from an award winning wellbeing specialist about:
the wellbeing continuum and the difference between mental illness prevention and wellbeing approaches
the key determinants that impact on staff wellbeing
effective strategies to respond to fatigue, burnout, depression and trauma
why one size doesn't fit all and how to scope and design a staff wellbeing programme responsive to the specific needs of your school
developing a staff wellbeing programme based on proven wellbeing outcomes
making informed decisions on your school’s staff wellbeing policy and activities
Workshop Format:
The content will be delivered over two workshops.
In-Person 1 day workshop in Wellington
Friday 31 October 9am to 4pm
On-Line Workshop
Wednesday 3 December 1 - 3.30pm

Topics covered in this practical workshop:
what is meant by wellbeing and its role in addressing stress and mental distress in staff;
the difference between a welfare and a wellbeing approach;
staff wellbeing as an industrial relations / conditions of employment issue
resilience, coping, thriving? - identifying desired wellbeing outcomes
the interface between personal and professional stressors and distressors
the impact on staff wellbeing from exposure to trauma and poor mental wellbeing within the student body
the key determinants that facilitate wellbeing in the teaching environment
what does and what doesn’t contribute to a supportive environment where staff thrive
the key components that should be in a staff wellbeing programme
designing, implementing and evaluating a staff wellbeing programme
School Group Participation
Schools are encouraged to have more than one staff member participate in the online workshops. Past workshops has shown that having more than one staff member has maximised the benefit of the workshop activities which can then been continued post-workshop. To promote school group participation, there is a 20% discount off the total registration fee when three or more participants per school are registered.
Who should attend: 
Senior leadership team members (especially those with responsibility of staff wellbeing)
OHS representatives or union delegates
Heads of Departments
Boards of Trustees representatives
School Counsellors / EAP providers
In-House Delivery:
This workshop can also be delivered in-house, school clusters, or organisations such as prinicpal assocations or unions. Post workshop consulting services such as mentoring the development of or reviewing a staff wellbeing plan can also be provided.
Post Workshop Consult:
Schools and Kuras have the option of a 90 minute consult with Barry in 2026 to review their staff wellbeing plan.
AN OPPORTUNITY FOR LEARNING WITH INTERNATIONALLY RESPECTED AND AWARD WINNING MENTAL WELLBEING PRACTITIONER AND SUICIDOLOGIST, BARRY TAYLOR
Barry has worked in mental wellbeing promotion and suicide prevention/postvention for 37 years at the local, national and international levels.  His extensive experience includes sitting on state and national government advisory committees; designing, implementing and evaluating suicide prevention programs; writing suicide prevention guidelines, training packages and community resources; providing technical advice to community based and national mental wellbeing and suicide prevention programs.  He has worked extensively with schools both here and overseas supporting management and staff in the event of a suicide. He wrote the first suicide postvention guidelines for schools in 1990, developed the first national suicide prevention guidelines for schools in Australia in 1999 and reviewed and updated the NZ guidelines in 2010.
He has led multiple ‘firsts’ in mental wellbeing both in Aotearoa New Zealand and overseas.  In recognition of his outstanding contribution to mental wellbeing and suicide prevention, he was awarded in 2016 the NSW Mental Health Commissioner's Community Champion Award.
Barry has lectured on wellbeing both nationally and internationally and been appointed to numerous government advisory committees on mental wellbeing and suicide prevention.  He brings to this workshop extensive experience in advising communities and government on post-disaster recovery in terms of both mental wellbeing promotion / community resiliency and suicide prevention.
As a Health Sociologist and Public Health practitioner, Barry has a long-term interest in the social and cultural determinants of wellbeing, especially the role of gender and he brings a wealth of knowledge and passion for promoting wellbeing in men. He has examined the impact of discrimination, internalised stigma, social exclusion or inclusion on mental wellbeing along with the role of human rights as an enabler of wellbeing.
He embraces a holistic understanding of wellbeing and has an interest in the role spirituality and ecology contributes to a person's wellbeing. He uses a population health and systems change approach, drawing on transformational change theory and collective impact.
After a number of years overseas, Barry is living back in New Zealand and is passionate about building the knowledge base, competence and capability within our country to promote well whānau, workplaces and communities and for the incorporation of wellbeing principles in public policy and social outcomes such as education, training and employment.

description:
Teaching Well - Supportive schools for a well staff - Wellington (TWS2025/04), With the growing emphasis on staff wellbeing there is a plethora of workplace mental wellbeing programmes on offer. However what is meant by staff wellbeing is not often clearly defined, with many programmes focusing on work related 'stressors' for staff or using staff wellness approach.  
As part of a well school, it is just essential to have a well staff as it is to a well student body. Take the opportunity to learn the underlying principles of wellbeing that inform a sustainable and impactful staff wellbeing plan.  
Designed specifically for the school context, the workshop examines the theory and the practice of promoting wellbeing through the lens of of being part of a school staff in 2025.
From Remedial to Sustainable Action
Equipping individual staff members skills or resources to cope more effectively with the stressful or distressing aspects of their jobs or providing an employee assistance programme is only one aspect of a comprehensive staff wellbeing plan. It is common for schools to start their development of their plan at the remedial end of the wellbeing continuum. Consequently the plan developed is more a welfare / wellness plan. Learn the difference between welfare, wellness and wellbeing approaches and the strengths and weaknesses of each approach. 

Meta-evaluations of workplace mental wellbeing programmes indicate that there is little evidence around the efficacy of many workplace wellbeing programmes because they do not address the organisational and systemic factors that act as either enablers of or obstacles to wellbeing. Just as it is recognised that supportive environments are foundational to wellbeing of students, so is it also for a well staff. An effective staff wellbeing programmes responds to the needs of the staff and reflects the cultural make-up of the staff, the values and character of the school. 
Drawing on collective impact and transformational change theory and Te Whare Tapa Whā, a conceptual model will be introduced that outlines the eight pou on which a staff wellbeing plan should be based. The strength of this model is that it settings or occupation specific. It requires a depth analysis of the nature, dynamics and demands of the work and the inter-relationships that occur in the work
Building of the learnings from previous workshops and feedback from participants, the workshop now offers a template to guide the development of a staff wellbeing plan
If you are wanting a workshop that will give you a pre-packaged wellbeing programme, then this workshop is not for you. Countless evaluations have shown the limited efficacy of wellbeing programmes that are "inserted" into a school. A staff wellbeing plan must grounded in and responsive to the learnings made out of the reflective analysis and staff consultation stages. In fact, the staff consultation is, in itself, is a wellbeing activity.
Take the opportunity to hear from an award winning wellbeing specialist about:
the wellbeing continuum and the difference between mental illness prevention and wellbeing approaches

description:
From Sad Blokes to Well Men: Changing the focus in male suicide prevention - Wellington (FSB2025/01), From anxious boys through to lonely old men: Tracking male suicide across the lifespan.
Are traditional notions of masculinity meeting the needs of men in 2025? How the changes in men’s roles and identity contribute to suicide in men.
A vision for men’s wellbeing: An holistic approach to conceptualising men’s wellbeing and key mental wellbeing messages for men.

IT'S TIME FOR A SERIOUS RETHINK IN HOW WE PREVENT MALE SUICIDE AND TO TAKE SUICIDE IN MEN OUT OF THE TOO HARD BASKET
Hear a comprehensive critique of why the suicide rate in men continues to rise despite numerous prevention initiatives, the reasons why we need to focus more on men and what are proven effective strategies for preventing male suicide.
BE PART OF THE SOLUTION
DURING THE MONTH OF MOVEMBER TAKE THE OPPORTUNITY TO PARTICIPATE  IN A WORKSHOP WITH INTERNATIONALLY RESPECTED AND AWARD WINNING MALE SUICIDE PREVENTION SPECIALIST BARRY TAYLOR
It matters that men are able to optimise their wellbeing.  Well men contribute to well whānau, communities, workplaces, economy and society
Drawing on his lived experience and his extensive experience in engaging, assessing and supporting suicidal men of different cultures, age groups, genders and sexualities, he offers practical and time proven approaches to both preventing male suicide, engaging with a suicidal man and effective initiatives to optimise men's wellbeing.
"Helping men and boys to transition from sad blokes to well men must be our focus"
Topics covered:
Overview of suicide in men
The Suicidal Moment - Men's thoughts, emotions and behaviour in the "suicidal moment”
Masculinity for the 21st Century - Are traditional notions of masculinity meeting the needs of men in 2024?  How the changes in men’s roles and identity contribute to suicide in men.
Intergenerational suicide among men and its impact of whānau and hapū
From anxious boys through to lonely old men: Tracking male suicide across the lifespan
A vision for men’s wellbeing: An holistic approach to conceptualising men’s wellbeing and key mental wellbeing messages for men.
Tāne Ora: An Online Masterclass in creating a movement of wellbeing for men by men
Participants would benefit from also registering for this online workshop series which takes a deep dive into the determinants of wellbeing men and what is required to shift very ingrained understandings in men about being a man.  How do we move from a program approach to mens wellbeing to a movement of change that engages men in conversations of the heart and the walrua. Click here for more information and to register
Previous participants’ feedback
"The best and most informative workshop I have attended in 27 years of mental health nursing”  Community Mental Health Nurse
"This workshop should be compulsory for anyone working with men”  Male Family Violence Worker
"It was as if Barry was talking about every young man I see at school”  School Counsellor
"I have much better understanding about depressed and suicidal men. Going away with lots of ideas of how work with the men in my community”  Rural Community Support Worker
"Thanks for being so inclusive of older men. They are so often forgotten”. Aged Care Worker
"The incorporation of Te Ao Māori into the training was excellent and made it relevant to the men I work with” Kaiwhakatere
"Most helpful workshop I have been to in regards to suicide”  Mental Health Recovery Programme Facilitator
"Appreciated how inclusive the presenter was of different cultures and his analysis of how culture influences what it means to be a man”  Refugee Health Worker
An opportunity for a day of learning with award winning suicidologist, Barry Taylor

Barry has worked in mental wellbeing promotion and suicide prevention / postvention for 36 years at the local, national and international levels.
His extensive experience includes sitting on state and national government advisory committees; designing, implementing and evaluating suicide prevention programs; writing suicide prevention guidelines, training packages and community resources; providing technical advice to and evaluating  community based and national mental wellbeing and suicide prevention programmes.
He has led multiple ‘firsts’ in the context of suicide prevention and postvention both in Aotearoa New Zealand and overseas. In recognition of his outstanding contribution to mental wellbeing and suicide prevention, he was awarded in 2016 the NSW Mental Health Commissioner's Community Champion Award. He currently sits one of the Health and Disability Ethics Committees.
As a health sociologist, Barry offers an unique insight into the phenomenon of male suicide in the Aotearoa-New Zealand context, the role of gender construction and the critical social and cultural determinants that have influenced men's distress and impaired wellbeing. Insights that very few others trainers or training programs in this country provide. He has had an interest on the impact of social exclusion, alienation and discrimination on mens's wellbeing and advocates for a human rights based, systems change and person-centred approach to wellbeing.The workshop is enriched by the learnings from Barry's own lived experience of depression and suicidality and his pathway to recovery.
After a number of years overseas, Barry is living back in New Zealand and is passionate about building the knowledge base, competence and capability within our country to effectively respond to the unacceptably high rate of male suicide in this country.

description:
The Art of Mending, When it comes to the clothes we love, every rip, stain, and imperfection is an invitation to exercise agency, expression, and an opportunity to show the garment how much we appreciate it.
This class is cared for by the whimsical Aisha, a multidisciplinary artist with a passion for empowering the mending process. Each month on Wednesday evenings Aisha will introduce us to a different technique for reviving our beloved textile pieces. If you're like us and have a box of clothing in need of repairs that never seems to empty... this is the club for you. With three events a month we'll inspire each other to creatively care for those pieces we love! This club is also perfect for anyone who loves learning new skills. Techniques we'll cover are lino printing, patching, darning, felting, embroidery, beading, sashiko, fabric painting and more! All materials and tools are supplied at each class - but you are welcome to bring your own. We highly encourage bringing those clothes or other textile items that need some love and repair.
There is no need to attend every class. We can catch you up on the skill at which ever class you choose to join us at. There are single class tickets or monthly sign ups available. Both of these have variable pricing options, unwaged/student, waged, and generous. Please choose whichever option feels right for you and your circumstances!
In August we are Lino Printing!
Class 02: 20th August
At this class Aisha will take us through the process of designing and cutting our own lino to print with! You're welcome to keep going with the pre cut designs as well. Lino and carving tools will be supplied.
Class 03: 27th August
This class will be open to what you want to work on! Bring in larger project items, print with the lino cuts you made in the previous week, or cut some fresh ones!
In September we are patching!
Class 01: 10th September
Aisha will take us through the process of sewing on patches. Patches that we printed in the August classes will be available for this. You're welcome to bring your own patches as well. Please bring something that needs a patch up or a little bit of decoration.
Class 02: 17th September
At this class we will learn how to appliqué, the process of using scrap fabric to make decorative patches. This is a great way to elevate a rip or stain with some visible mending.
Class 03: 24th September
At this last class of the month we'll be open for all the patching needs. Hang out and finish projects we've started or mend some extra items.
Be sure to check our website or here for updates about techniques coming up in the following months.
label: Conservation, Environment

description:
COFFEE & CLAY Hand build your own ceramic butter dish, Join us for a relaxed, hands-on workshop where you'll create your very own ceramic butter dish in a working pottery studio. Over two inspiring hours, you'll learn the basics of hand-building with clay, guided step-by-step by a ceramic artist.
Enjoy fresh coffee and a home-baked morning tea as you get creative with shaping, decorating, and embellishing your piece. You'll finish by choosing your preferred glaze colours, and we'll take care of the firing process. Your finished butter dish will be ready to collect approximately four weeks later.
This small group workshop is perfect for absolute beginners—no experience needed. Come solo and meet like-minded creatives, or bring a friend for a fun and mindful morning.
You’ll be amazed at how calming it is to get out of your head and into your hands!

description:
The Art of the Bloom- Make a Giant Flower, Step into the cozy charm of the Ventana studio and spend a hands-on crafternoon learning to create your very own voluminous, oversized crepé paper flower- a sculptural statement piece that’s equal parts art and joy.
In this immersive workshop, you’ll be guided through every step of the process from choosing the perfect colour palette to cutting, curling, shaping, and assembling each petal by hand. It’s a meditative, rewarding craft that requires patience, but with the right techniques (and a few of my favourite tricks!), you’ll be amazed at what you can create.

description:
Manawa Karioi Working Bees, Our track maintenance and planting working bees are focussing on plant species diversity rather than large planting quantities. We have ordered 500 special trees from the Berhampore Nursery. We are in this for the long haul and a forest that contains a wide range of plant species will, in turn, attract a wider range of birds, lizards, and invertebrates. A wider range of plant species also allows for the forest to naturally regenerate and helps prevent weed species from establishing.
Tools are provided, bring sturdy shoes and a water bottle, Working bees are held every Sunday in June (except June 1st - Kings Birthday Weekend) and August 2025.
Meeting at the Information Shelter in the Tapu te Ranga Marae car park at the end of Danube Street in Island Bay. Children are welcome with parents or guardians.

description:
Integrating Creative Writing Into Painting - 4 Week Course, Creative writing and painting are both powerful forms of artistic expression. By integrating creative writing into your painting practice, you can enhance your imagination, storytelling abilities, emotional expression, attention to detail, and personal style on the canvas. Please bring along a journal or laptop.

COURSE CONTENT
Each session presents a key idea backed by research or concrete examples, followed by practical writing exercises with optional sharing. We learn by doing and from each other.

1. Generating work from the interior: tapping into memories, conflict, emotion, and observation to generate art.
2. Figuring out what matters to you, then learning how to grow your fragmented ideas into something whole. For example, how do you turn a feeling, or a fleeting moment in time into a story? Into a painting? Into a work of art? What are the building blocks you need?
3. Inspiration from other creative sources: people, music, poetry, reading, random incidents. Ways to generate fresh ideas. How to clarify and focus in writing and art.
4. Structure and boundaries. Dreaming big but being real. How do you find and stick to a creative process? Understanding how you learn and what kind of feedback you need. Designing your next project.

Thursday mornings, 9:30 - 11:45 am.
4 - 25 September.

Led by one of our skilled baristas at The Hangar, this hands-on workshop will take you through the fundamentals of milk steaming and latte art in clear, in-depth steps. You'll learn how to texture milk properly and pour a range of basic designs with confidence.

description:
Jewellery Making Intensive - Beginners' Workshop, Join us for a fun day learning the skills to make your own jewellery, using sterling silver and copper or brass. All materials included in course fee.

Description
Learn the essential skills and techniques needed to make your own creations. The morning will begin with simple design examples and techniques using specialist jewellers’ tools, working with copper or brass. In the afternoon you will form and craft your own ring from sterling silver.

All materials included in course fee. Please bring pen and paper and wear clothing and footwear suitable for a workshop environment. Limited to nine participants.
Please note you cannot be late for this one-day course, you must be there from the start of the course when health and safety matters are covered.

By the end of the course, you'll be able to:
- Create a silver band
- Demonstrate techniques for soldering sterling silver
- Perform metal forming, piercing and texturing skills
- Use essential jewellery-making tools accurately

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

description:
Life Drawing Meets Yoga!, Connect with your body and your creativity in this all-levels workshop that combines vinyasa yoga practice with a fun and interactive Life Drawing class!

A unique experience where movement meets mark-making. We begin with yoga and flow into life drawing until the two become naturally intertwined.

The drawing process is fully guided and inspired by the philosophies and methods of British artist Cecil Collins, encouraging a non-academic, intuitive approach. Through playful interaction with asana, the connection between these two practices becomes beautifully apparent.

Drinks and nibbles follow, along with a chance for kōrero and connection.

Guided by JoElle Gragilla, owner of Island Bay’s South Coast Studio, and AWHI yoga teacher Lachlan Broughton.

Encouraging expression over perfection, this experience is open to all levels and accessible to both artists and non-artists alike.

Come curious. Leave inspired.

Investment
$75 (includes all drawing materials, yoga, mat hire, drinks & nibbles)

All supplies & props provided — wear comfortable clothing to move in!

description:
Glass Bead-Making Taster, Join us for this fabulous introduction to working with colourful molten glass!

This class is a great way for absolute beginners to get a taste of working with glass to produce beautiful beads that can be used in a myriad of ways, including making a unique gift for your loved one (or yourself!).

As one of the earliest forms of human adornment, beads have long functioned as a way to express individuality, and what better way to do that than to learn to make your own unique beads?

Students are shown correct lampworking techniques to produce several decorative beads in just 3 hours! How many beads you make is up to you, some students make up to 10 while others make fewer using trickier techniques.

Kids over 12 (or so) are welcome to take the class but anyone under 16 must be accompanied by an enrolled parent or caregiver.

description:
Textured Rings - Welcome Spring!, Make your own personalised ring - a gift for yourself or someone special! :-)

Learn the basic technique first in copper or brass, and then craft your final piece in silver!

Over this taster class, you’ll be guided through the process of heating and texturing metal, cutting and shaping with traditional jewellery tools. Use feathers, leaves, or fabrics to create a unique texture for a beautiful ring!

Learn to measure your finger, cut metal to length and texture it without rolling mill, hammers and punches. Then use a jewellers torch, sandpaper and polishing, and your beautiful new ring will be ready to wear.

This 3-hour class is ideal for beginners, groups of friends and visitors to the city.

Included in the class fee are copper and brass for practising on, a sterling silver ring strip and all consumables such as sandpaper, solder and chemicals. Extra metals are available for purchase in the studio.

Kids aged 12 (or so) are welcome to attend the class, but any person under the age of 16 must be accompanied by an enrolled parent or caregiver.

Students will learn correct tool use and gain a solid understanding of the lampwork process. They will also learn some ways of incorporating their beads into wearable jewellery with silver and/or stainless-steel findings

Course cost includes set materials, such as glass and stainless-steel findings. Silver, findings and extra glass are available to purchase in the studio.

description:
Leadlight Glass - 4 Weeks Block, Learn to create gorgeous leadlight designs with our experienced jewellers! This great course runs from Friday 12 September for 4 weeks until Friday 3 October, 5.30pm - 8pm.

Your 4-week block will give you time to learn the basics and then create one or more leadlight projects.

This class is ideal for creating sun-catchers or small decorative projects for beginners, or working on slightly more complex pieces for those with some experience.

Beginners will start by planning their design, then learning to cut the glass, and prepare it before foiling and soldering each piece, creating a simple elegant clear glass starter project.

Beautiful coloured glass, copper foil and leadlight solder are then available to purchase as required for your other projects.

This is a warm and friendly class with excellent support and learning for complete beginners and more advanced students. All tools are supplied, though you are welcome to bring your own tools and glass if you have them.

Your materials for your beginner project are supplied as part of your course fee, extra materials will be available for purchase if you wish to make larger pieces or more than one project.

description:
Water Cast Pendants Taster - Spring, This is a super quick 3-hour session, and is great fun to do with family or friends.

Water casting is a really hands-on low-tech casting method that results in surprising and fun little forms that can be turned into pendants with amazing textures and shapes.

You will be guided through melting silver and pouring it into water to create little charms.

Experiment with pouring at different heights to create different shapes.
Choose one or a few of your favourites to have drilled and turn into simple pendants or earrings, or new charms for your bracelets!

We will use hardened jump rings to attach your water-cast pieces to either colourful cord or you can choose sterling silver chains which you can purchase for extra.

The technique will be demonstrated with important health and safety practices, then students will be guided to do at least a couple of casts, and should expect to have at least one successful item to clean up and finish in the class.

A basic amount of metal allowance of a small amount of silver is included in your course costs, and if your projects go over that amount you can pay for the metal you use on the day via internet banking or cash.

This course is open to complete beginners and advanced makers. Extra materials such as chains and findings are available to purchase.

For health and safety reasons class participants must wear sturdy, closed toe shoes and have their hair tied back.

description:
Foundations of Leadership - Extended, The purpose of this course is to provide you with a solid foundation in leadership principles and practical skills to apply in real-world situations. 
By understanding these fundamental aspects, you will be better prepared to take on leadership roles and inspire your people. 
The course spans two days, covering eight modules that focus on the most important knowledge a new leader requires. These modules deliver hands-on skills rooted in leadership theory. 

Key audience
This course is suitable for people who are new to leadership and would like the theory and practice that provides a foundation for a successful leadership career. It is also beneficial for those who have been in a new role for a while that requires some leadership expertise. 

Learning outcomes
Understand the basic concepts of leadership
Develop effective communication skills as a leader
Learn how to confidently empower your people and build effective teams
Demonstrate good decision-making and problem-solving skills
Identify effective ways to manage conflict as a leader
Understand the importance of self-awareness and continuous development

If you would like to register with Business Central directly and receive an invoice for payment, please contact our training team via training@businesscentral.org.nz.

Duration: Two day, in person course.
Time: 9am–4pm, both days

Course includes:
Workbook, arrival tea or coffee, morning tea, lunch, and afternoon tea.
To view our Terms and Conditions click here.
