description:
Biochar Big Day Out 2025, Char curious? Keen gardener? Orchardist? Lifestyler? Climate Champion? BBQ enthusiast? 
Come one, come all to this one-off opportunity to spend a day making biochar in a magical orchard, forest and garden. Thank you Kapiti Coast District Council (KCDC) and Paekākāriki Orchards and Gardens (POG) for sponsoring this event so we can offer subsidised tickets as part of Sustainable Spring!
You will:

Morning sessions (9.30-12)...
Sipping coffee and learning the basics of Biochar. 
Getting hands-on exploring the property and learning to source good burn material (stuff you can find in your own backyard or lifestyle block).
Building a char toilet - great skills for civil defence emergencies, or just camping!
Ignite the Char-B-Que and BIG 600l kiln, learn how to feed the flames and trap the carbon.
Cooking using char!
At lunchtime (12-1)...
Enjoy a BBQ lunch cooked on the Char-B-Que. 
Learn all about the magic of biochar and how to use it to fight climate change, feed your garden. 
After lunch sessions (1-3)...
Quenching (pour cold water on) a kiln and processing char by drying and crushing it.
Making a home fireplace mini kiln using a biscuit tin (please bring a tin if you have one or koha for some extra we will source and bring from op shops).
Making a char water filter.
At the end of the day (3 pm)
Grab some biochar to take home (BYO container e.g. ice-cream tub or a small bucket
The big kiln will be quenched later in the day (around 4pm). For those keen to level up their learning on the kind of kilns used for large lifestyle blocks and small farms you are welcome to stay on and participate in a small advanced group dicussion and actvities between 3 and 4.30pm. 
Important things to note: 
Sustainability: 
We encourage carpooling to the event. Please bring your own reusable cup for hot drinks
Health and Safety:
 Please note there will be tree nuts and hazards onsite such as hot kilns and flames. So please take the necessary precautions by wearing non-flammable (cotton, wool, natural) materials and bring any personal medication that you need. We will have a health and safety volunteer onsite.

Family Friendly:
 It is a family-friendly event (kids under 18 are free) but they must be supervised by their parent or guardian at all times due to the hazards on site. 
Workshop Leaders 
John Wraight - CharPae 
Our CharPae Operations manager and ‘inhouse’ Biochar subject matter expert John Wraight has been making and using Biochar for many years and has delivered a number of successful workshops using these kilns. He is a BioChar Network member. He leads local CharPae burns, Char-B-Ques and kiln hire.
Holly Norton - CharPae 
Our CharPae Project manager has been making and using Biochar for the past 2 years. She co-leads these workshops and has additionally been exploring char use in sustainable construction and civil defence. She is currently on a mission to use Biochar to transform a tennis court into a thriving kai production space. She is this event's coordinator should you have any questions.

description:
Cultivating a Positive Workplace Culture for High-Performance Teams, This course is designed for leaders, managers, and organisational change agents who want to foster a positive workplace culture that drives high performance, collaboration, and employee wellbeing. Participants will explore the essential principles of creating an environment that nurtures trust, accountability, inclusivity, and engagement. Through practical strategies, case studies, and interactive discussions, participants will learn how to develop a culture that motivates teams to excel, encourages open communication, and supports professional growth.

Key Topics Include:
• Building a culture of trust and psychological safety
• Fostering open communication and feedback loops
• Aligning values and purpose with organisational goals
• Promoting inclusivity, diversity, and belonging
• Recognising and celebrating achievements
• Encouraging work-life balance and wellbeing
• Developing strategies for conflict resolution and collaboration
By the end of the course, participants will have the tools and insights needed to create a workplace environment that not only supports but accelerates the success of high-performing teams, driving both individual and collective achievement.

Key audience:
This course is designed for leaders, managers, and anyone responsible for shaping the culture within their teams and organisations.

Learning outcomes:
Implement strategies to cultivate trust, psychological safety, and high performance within their teams.
Lead teams that foster open communication, collaboration, and inclusivity.
Align team goals with organisational values and objectives, ensuring a shared sense of purpose.
Develop effective strategies for conflict resolution and team cohesion.
Create a workplace culture that encourages growth, well-being, and work-life balance.

If you would like to register with Business Central directly and receive an invoice for payment, please contact our training team via training@businesscentral.org.nz.

Course details:
Duration: Full day, in person.
Time: 9am – 4pm
Course includes
Workbook, arrival tea or coffee, morning tea, lunch, afternoon tea.
To view our Terms and Conditions click here.

The Wellington City Shake-em-on-Downers ARE BACK proving themselves to be the most resilient life form on the planet, giving even the cockroaches a run for their money. Middle New Zealand's favourite dadaist swing cult phenomenon are back with a vengeance, serving up a fiery primordial soup of fresh tunes for your listening and dancing 'pleasure'. Prepare for the stupidest gags, hottest horn solos, stonkiest grooves and pea-brained banter as we reign supreme in the battle of wits and people's attention against the existential crisis rectangle, otherwise know as the iPhone. description:
Terry Shore, Terry Shore has been a real stalwart around the local Wellington music scene for over 30 years, playing his own original music both solo and with the Volun Terry Band.

He has 5 albums, 2 more on the way, and 3 EP's to his credit since releasing his first Poly Rhythm album in 2010. For the last 20 years he has run a programme on Wellington Access Radio showcasing unknown songwriters called Terry's Songwriters Show which airs on Saturdays at 2:30pm.

Terry has written memorable original catchy pop songs such as Anything, Dancing On The Line Island Love, Galactica Calling, The Daleks Are Coming In and many more.

He will be playing at the Undercurrent on Sunday 24th August from 5:30pm performing his originals with electric acoustic guitar and MP3 backing tracks. Stay on after the Sunday Jazz and see Terry for a good entertaining show!

Sunday 24th August
5:30pm
$15 online/ door
$20 for entry and CD

Complimentary snacks, wine, beer & soft drinks, tea & coffee, and of course...books available for purchase!
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Tom Cunliffe & Ali Whitton – Vogelmorn, Tom Cunliffe & Ali Whitton – big hearts, remarkable songs – on stage, with a collection of brand new tunes.
Doors at 7
Music at 7.30
The Upstairs Bar and Smoked and Pickled Restaurant will be open from 3pm, to book a table for pre-show kai email Alice at smokednpickled@gmail.com
-----------------
Tom Cunliffe writes folk songs like short films; vivid, offbeat, and full of heart. Based in Tamaki Makaurau, Auckland, he crafts lyrical worlds, with a guitar tuned sideways and a voice that balances gravity with joy.
Cunliffe has supported a number of internationally renowned artists including M. Ward, Grace Cummings, and Reb Fountain, bringing his mix of warmth, wit, and slow-burning intensity to stages near and far.
-----------------
Ali Whitton is an Aotearoa-born, Yorkshire-raised and now Wellington based singer-songwriter who is stepping into his own as an artist. Ali is an artist who refuses to let go, blending raw storytelling with a sound shaped by decades of experience and dedication to his craft.
Performing for years under the name Lost Bird, Ali built a reputation for writing heartfelt, melancholic folk-pop, playing everywhere from Wellington bars to stadium stages — including opening for Ed Sheeran in Auckland in 2018.
Now, after years of performing behind an alias, Ali is stepping forward under his own name, embracing his identity as an artist with an invigorated sense of purpose, and tackling his artistry with newfound confidence and clarity.
-----------------
Vogelmorn Upstairs is not a wheelchair accessible building. There is an accessible bathroom in the space. This is an all ages venue but those under the age of 16 must be accompanied by a designated adult after 8pm. The Vogelmorn Precinct is a community space located in a residential area. With that in mind, the team ask that you be kind to others' and that when you leave the gig, you do so quietly to avoid disturbing our neighbours.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Debt Club EP Release Show W/ Model Home & Wiri Donna, Debt Club celebrate the release of their debut EP “Taste For Stout” with a special show in Pōneke, joined by friends and powerhouse live acts Model Home and Wiri Donna.
Formed in 2023, Debt Club have quickly made their mark with a dynamic, guitar-driven sound that blends anthemic hooks with thoughtful lyricism. Following the release of singles “Little Lines” and “Windows,” both featured on “Taste For Stout”, the band are set to mark this milestone with their biggest show yet.
Ōtautahi legends Model Home bring their kiwi take on midwest emo, earning massive attention with their 2023 debut album “…And Nobody Made A Sound” and a bunch of student radio hits.
Wiri Donna, led by Bianca Bailey, are a commanding indie rock force whose high energy shows and acclaimed EP’s Being Alone and In My Chambers have made them one of Aotearoa’s most exciting live acts.
San Fran holds a Supervised License. Minors are welcome to attend events at San Fran so long as they are accompanied by a legal guardian at all times whilst at the venue.

description:
MINUIT : The Reunion Shows | PŌNEKE (Wellington), SOLD OUT!!!!
After over a decade away, legendary NZ electronic act Minuit are back – and bringing their iconic live show to Wellington.
..................................................................................................
This reunion makes us very happy because we thought it might never happen – ‘the Kiwi band with the French name’ are back together for a series of shows.
Singer, Ruth, describes the gigs as: "a chance to dance, laugh and sing (in my case, often the wrong words), together live one more time."
Minuit (minwee) became a must-see live act through the 2000s. Fronted by the enigmatic Ruth Carr, her coy persona ignites while bandmates Ryan Beehre and Paul Dodge forge rib-rattling beats around her.
Their debut album, The 88, released in 2003, achieved gold status in New Zealand, quickly followed up by the 'I Hate Guns' EP.
Over the following decade, the trio toured their synths and samplers from Helsinki to Hanoi crafting their own refreshing sound – storming The Crystal Method's club night in LA, the FabricLive birthday bash in London, and headlining the Hanoi Music Festival in Vietnam. Along with festivals and shows up and down Aotearoa.
Having been retired since 2014, we’re excited to announce that Minuit are back onstage for a limited number of reunion shows.
These reunion performances will pay tribute to classic tunes from all four albums 'The Boy with the Aubergine Hair', 'Except You', 'Fuji', 'Menace', ‘Aotearoa’, ‘I Hate Guns’, ‘A Room Full of Cute’, 'Last Night You Saw This Band', ‘25 Bucks’ – everything gets a look in, plus a couple of other surprises.
The show will be supported by Western Haikus and JOLA BURNS.
Minuit has a heart. And it beats loud. Real loud.

description:
Christine Wang and Rachel Thomson -- Violin and Piano, Join us for Ravel's Violin and Piano Sonata No. 2 and de Falla's Suite Populaire Espagnole based on “Siete canciones populares españolas,” along with Ginastera's hauntingly beautiful Pampeana No. 1, Op. 16 - Rhapsody for Violin and Piano.

Christine Wang, violin

Christine has been a member of the second violin section of New Zealand Symphony Orchestra since 2022. She holds a Bachelor of Music from Eastman School of Music and Master of Music at Rice University, studying under Oleh Krysa and Kathleen Winkler respectively. Before coming to New Zealand, Christine was Assistant Concertmaster of San Antonio Symphony and has worked in orchestras in the United States and Australia.

Rachel Thomson, piano

Rachel Thomson was born in Dunedin, New Zealand, and grew up in Wellington where she began her piano studies with her mother. She went on to study with Judith Clark, graduating from Victoria University of Wellington before continuing her studies at the Cleveland Institute of Music in the United States, where she gained a doctorate in piano performance. Rachel regularly performs with some of the country’s leading musicians. She has toured on numerous occasions for Chamber Music New Zealand and is a member of various chamber ensembles including the Koru Trio. She has worked as an orchestral pianist with the NZSO, Orchestra Wellington, and the Christchurch Symphony Orchestra. Rachel is also active as a teacher, adjudicator and accompanist, and is a music examiner for Trinity College London.

With Ashley Hale-Durham, Georgie Sullivan, Jude Madill, and Julie Lamb leading the charge, and a stellar band backing them up, it's bound to be a night of high-energy performances.

This from our last gig...

"Man did they ROCK! 4 very talented ladies and awesome band... the venue was rocking - check them out!"

An electrifying time warp! The 70s were a golden era for rock, with bands like Journey, Led Zeppelin, Whitesnake, and Deep Purple defining the sound of an entire generation. The idea of powerhouse female vocalists fronting a live band, belting out classics from these legends, is pure magic.

Early bird tickets are just $20, while door sales are $30—so it's definitely worth grabbing them early. This show is going to be an absolute blast, so securing those cheaper tickets ahead of time is a smart move.

description:
The Cowpokers + Tyson Smith, THE COWPOKERS: Foot-tappin' Onekaka Swamp Rock, World Famous in Golden Bay!

Golden Bay's finest local boys are rounding up and riding North to bring their unique brand of rock, blues and ska to the capital. What if swamp rock wasn't born in Louisiana, but in Takaka you ask? What if Iggy Pop and the Stooges had been Marlborough dairy farmers? What if Hendrix had settled in a Tukurua art gallery selling homemade jewellery crafted from shells and bone? The answer to all these questions and more can be found at a Cowpokers gig: a raw, barn-storming, rural-rock-and-roll sensation that 23 years of gigging has utterly failed to hone, polish, or refine.

TYSON SMITH: Wellington-based guitarist/singer/songwriter Tyson Smith will be bringing his unique, original music combining elements of rock, blues, folk, world music and freeform improvisation.

Tyson has worked as a guitarist with acts ranging from the New Zealand Symphony Orchestra to vocalist Hollie Smith, before focusing on his own music in the last few years.
In 2024 he celebrated 10 years since the release of his album The Hollow Tree with Rick Cranson and Ed Zuccollo, and released his new single Wolves. Tyson has been performing regularly around various New Zealand venues and festivals with his raw and exciting sound both with the trio and solo (utilising multiple amps and a bass drum).

description:
Echoes of Home: A Musical Journey Across Time, Event Information
Some days remind us who we are and where we come from — when an entire nation moves as one to honour Independence.
To celebrate the 80th Anniversary of Vietnam’s National Day (2 September), Viet Hub NZ proudly presents
“Echoes of Home – A Musical Across Time”
This free concert is a heartfelt journey through the sounds of Vietnamese history — from nostalgic childhood songs to powerful wartime ballads and modern melodies of pride and hope. All performances will include English subtitles, making it easy for everyone to follow along and connect with the stories.
Whether you’re Vietnamese or simply curious about a different culture, this is a wonderful opportunity to experience the warmth, resilience, and beauty of Vietnam through music and storytelling.
🎁 Raffle with Over $300 in Prizes
Don’t miss our special raffle on the day. Tickets will be available at the venue for $5 and $10. Payment can be made in cash or by bank transfer.
💛 Support Viet Hub NZ
This event is free to attend, but if you believe in what we do and want to help us continue running community workshops, cultural events, and youth-led initiatives — please consider making a donation.
👉 Donate here: https://givealittle.co.nz/cause/viet-hub-nz-rooted-in-culture-powered-by-community
Your koha helps keep our work going, rooted in culture, powered by community.

description:
Amanda Bunting and Kris Zuelicke, Solos and Duets for Piano, Leo Smit - Divertimento

Ginastera - No. 2 from Danzas Argentinas, op. 2 - "Danza de la moza donosa"

Ravel - Sonatine, M. 40, Movement I - Modéré

Schubert - "Lebensstürme," Allegro in A minor, D 947

Amanda Bunting is a graduate of the New Zealand School of Music, completing her Bachelor of Music with Honours in 2019 in solo piano performance with Dr. Jian Liu; small group ensemble with Dr. Rolf Gjelsten; and performance and embodiment studies with Dr. Hamish Robb and Dr. Margaret Medlyn. Prior to that, she completed a Graduate Diploma in Music in performance piano, performance studies, and pedagogy.

After previously studying with Gillian Bibby at the Conservatorium of Music and graduating in 1996, Amanda chose to return to study to further develop performance skills, enhance her own piano performance abilities and to gain further knowledge that can be shared with her piano students. Amanda is an Associate of the Institute of Registered Music Teachers New Zealand, a member of the Wellington Branch and currently works both as a Piano Teacher and a Human Resources Adviser at Victoria University of Wellington.

Kris Zuelicke grew up in a theatrical and musical family, accompanying shows and choirs from high school onwards. In the USA, she gained degrees in Music (BA Miami University) and Music Theory (MA Indiana University) and taught music along with other subjects at the Bloomington Montessori School.

In Karlsruhe, Germany Kris taught at the Landau Montessori School, Berlitz Language School, courses on theatre and music at the Teacher’s College and piano privately. She studied with Annemi Egri and Sariel Maler during this time.

Kris currently teaches in five schools around Wellington, maintains a thriving private piano and cello studio and accompanies students at the New Zealand School of Music. Her most recent degree is in harpsichord performance (DMA NZSM), including study and research in Boston with Mark Kroll. Kris enjoys performing regularly with other musicians, including piano duets, chamber music and has enjoyed projects with Stroma, the Queen’s Closet and a fun stint as a harpsichordist extra in the recently released Time Bandits.

description:
The Racket Lounge: Session Three, Grab a spot on our couch and enjoy the noise at The Racket Lounge, a chill classical music series featuring up-and-coming Pōneke classical and jazz musicians.

Last year the NZSQ Trust launched the Racket Lounge, a concert series for classical and jazz musicians with experience ranging from students to pros to freely express their creativity in a non-traditional concert setting. It was a huge success, with over 250 audience members and 52 artists over our four sessions. Audiences were raving about the musical variety and great talent they found at the Racket Lounge, and as one audience member commented; “Well done…do it again!” So, we listened, and the Racket Lounge is back for round two! Once again hosted at Bedlam & Squalor (above the Rogue & Vagabond), we welcome audiences, composers and performers back for another four concerts full of innovative, fun, and chill music. From classical to pop covers, video game soundtracks to original compositions, there's something for everyone to sink their teeth into at The Racket Lounge!

Even if you've never been to a classical music concert before, this one is for you. With a 'Choose your price' model you can afford to give it a go - and you might even find something you like!

A Flexible Price, So You Can Take A Chance on Something New:
Our prices range from $5 to $100, just pick the ticket price you feel like paying. At The Racket Lounge, we believe everyone should have access to high-quality but affordable art. If you're a bit strapped for cash right now, but still want a good night out, no worries! Just book yourself a $5 ticket! If you can afford to pay a little more and want to do some good for your community, then pick one of our higher ticket prices and rest assured that your dollars are going towards funding great, accessible art in your city.

All proceeds from ticket sales will go directly into presenting the next Racket Lounge, including paying musicians and artists, hiring instruments and marketing costs. Plus, by choosing a higher price point, you're ensuring that we're able to continue to offer tickets at a lower price point for those who need it.

Please note: Bedlam & Squalor is a licenced venue, so under 18s must be accompanied by a parent or legal guardian. Everyone must bring ID.
label: Music & Concerts

With support from Frances Grass.

description:
Jazz Orchestra Composer Series Presents: John Rae, Award-winning composer and musician John Rae invites you to an
enchanting evening of Celtic-inspired music that promises to get your feet tapping and your ears thumping. This large ensemble draws on both new and traditional melodies, reimagined in a style that reflects Rae’s cultural roots and personal musical journey. Experience a vibrant celebration of Celtic heritage through engaging rhythms and rich harmonies that showcase the versatility and depth of contemporary Celtic music.
John has recorded over 30 albums as a leader and side man including two BBC Jazz Albums of the Year (2003 and 2004). He has performed with the Scottish National Jazz Orchestra, was the first ever Jazz Composer in Residence at Victoria University, has written music for the NZSO/Wellington Jazz Orchestra and RNZAF Concert Band, and has toured internationally with his eclectic chamber ensemble "The Troubles".
The Jazz Orchestra Composer Series showcases original music for large jazz ensemble by New Zealand composers. Concerts take place every 1st and 3rd Friday of the month, from May to October, from 7pm. Tickets are $15, door sales $20.

Thanks to Creative New Zealand for their generous support.

description:
Jazz in Martinborough 2025, Big Band Brings Back the Swing
Jazz in Martinborough 2025

Jazz in Martinborough is thrilled to be bringing you the Royal New Zealand Airforce Jazz Orchestra as our feature act on Saturday at the festival for 2025.

“We’re delighted to be able to fill the stage with a full-sized big band of fabulous musicians, and the Town Hall with the fantastic sounds of the big band era,” says Jazz in Martinborough Music Director Lee Quayle.

Jazz in Martinborough is back for their 13th edition during the first weekend in September with ticketed shows on Friday 5th and Saturday 6th and other gigs around town as usual. “The RNZAF Jazz Orchestra will be one of our ticketed gigs, featuring on the Saturday evening,” says Lee. “And on Friday night we invite you to Be Transported back in time to a speak easy club with the superb swing and blues combo that is April’s Fools,” adds Lee.

Staying true to the tradition of swing and improvisation the RNZAF Jazz Orchestra draws on their own rich history dating back to the original ‘swing era’. The Orchestra is a national trailblazer in big band history and features New Zealand compositions, and a classic repertoire from the golden era of big band swing jazz of Ellington and Basie.

The band benefits from a depth of talent that most military bands around the world would only dream of and is made up of Wellington’s most exceptional musicians.

“The line-up will be a who’s who of the Wellington jazz scene,” says Lee. “It’s a while since we had a big band at the festival, so we’re elated to have the Airforce Jazz Orchestra back with us again. They last played at the festival in 2014. Many of the band members have been here since, but not as part of a big band,” says Lee.

Be Transported by April’s Fools
Imagine stepping back in time to a speak easy club. A smoky, dimly lit room where the anticipation is electric but the vibe is laid-back and relaxed. . .

From the stage a jazz swing and blues band begins to play, their instruments blending seamlessly in a harmonious symphony of sound. The rhythm section, with its upright bass and snare drums, lays down a groove that's impossible to resist, while the saxophone punctuates the air with soulful notes.

At. the forefront stands a captivating female singer, her voice rich and velvety, weaving tales of heartache, joy, and everything in between. Her vocal prowess brings both swing and blues to life, effortlessly moving from sultry, slow blues ballads to energetic, foot-tapping swing numbers.

This band doesn't just play music; they create an experience that transports the audience to another era, where the essence of jazz and blues reigns supreme.

Welcome to an evening of superb swing jazz and blues brought to you by the band that is April’s Fools. “We’re absolutely wrapt to be bringing this ultra-talented and experienced combo to the festival,” says Music Director Lee Quayle. “Whenever, and wherever this group of musicians have played reviewers have to search the thesaurus for new superlatives to describe the show, and audiences leave reluctantly, but happy.”

April’s Fools are April Phillips (vocals), Greg Crayford (drums), Zak Dikvert (guitar), Nicholas Bauke-Maunsell (saxophone), Miles Crayford (keyboards) and RoryMacartney (bass). They will be playing at Jazz in Martinborough on Friday 5 September 2025 as the opening of the ticketed festival gigs to be held in the Town Hall.

description:
Wairarapa Youth Orchestra: Around The World With Music, Get ready for a global classical musical journey as the Wairarapa Youth Orchestra presents their special concert, “Around the World with Music”!
The vibrant sounds of violins, flutes, cellos, trombones, and more will fill the Wairarapa Events Centre, Carterton as our young musicians from across the Wairarapa share their hard work. These talented tamariki and rangatahi are now ready to take you on an unforgettable adventure through sound.

Under the expert guidance of conductor Andrew Atkins and our dedicated tutors, the Wairarapa Youth Orchestra has been diligently preparing a diverse program that celebrates music from various continents. Prepare to be captivated by everything from the rhythmic pulse of African drums to the sweeping melodies of European symphonies, including the grandeur and pomp of Tchaikovsky’s 1812 Overture, and evocative folk tunes echoing the sounds of Asia. It’s a unique opportunity to experience a rich tapestry of sounds, all brought to life by the passion and talent of our local youth.

This inspiring event is more than just a performance; it’s a vital fundraiser. The Wairarapa Youth Orchestra offers free orchestral music learning to young people throughout the Wairarapa, and we rely entirely on fundraising and donations to keep this invaluable program thriving. Your attendance directly supports the continued musical education of our community’s youth.

Excitingly for 2025, we will be adding three new venues: St Peter's on Willis, Flying Nun Records and 13 Garrett Street (sponsored by Radio Active), as well as a travelling electronic stage curated by Tonic Collective. Juxtaposing Renaissance melodies and polyphony with the rich virtuosity and colour of Baroque instruments, intimate vocal solos with a choir and orchestra of unprecedented grandeur, and dazzling opulence with striking emotional and spiritual depth, this will be an unmissable performance

description:
BANDIT QUEEN @ The Boathouse, Nelson, BANDIT QUEEN is NZ's finest (likely only) tribute to the music of The Decemberists.A Tribute to the Decemberists? BUT WHO ARE THE DECEMBERISTS?
Hailing from Portland Oregon, The Decemberists is an indie-alt folk rock band that write epic songs and have 9 studio albums to their credit. They are renowned for their musical style and unique storytelling with many song lyrics based on historical incidents and folklore. Perhaps drawing musical influence from the likes of The Beatles, Tom Waits, REM, Morrisey, their songs are exquisitely constructed and effortlessly combine folk-rock with elements of pop creating the infectious sound that is The Decemberists.
And who is BANDIT QUEEN? Experienced Christchurch based musos - Tim Kent (vocals, acoustic guitar); Justin 'Rusty' White (lead guitar); Jo-Anne Davern Fuller (vocals, keyboard); Chiara Lowe (violin, vocals); Adam Lowe (bass); Mark Newburn (drums, percussion).
The members of BANDIT QUEEN are passionate about this project and invite you to come experience and enjoy the eclectic music of USA indie-rock band THE DECEMBERISTS.

description:
Wellington Jazz Festival, Soul, funk, jazz, fusion, rhythm and blues — it’s a celebration of sound across the city this spring. The annual Wellington Jazz Festival is back. The event packs over 100 gigs into five days in venues around the city. 
The festival features two major international acts making exclusive New Zealand debuts. Wellington will see two-time Grammy Award-winning jazz vocalist and bandleader, Gregory Porter and five-time Grammy Award-winning jazz singer, Samara Joy. Gregory Porter’s unique and timeless sound blends jazz, soul, and gospel. His influences include Bakersfield Southern Gospel and jazz legend Nat King Cole. At just 25 years old, Samara Joy has become a breakout jazz sensation. She’s redefining 21st-century jazz with a rich, mature tone and refined phrasing. 
The treats in the programme continue with Australian First Nations soul singer Bumpy, and a commissioned work by New Zealand/Congolese drummer, composer, and rhythm master  Myele Manzanza. He’ll be performing with international supergroup, lvdf. The Rodger Fox Big Band returns with a tribute to Ray Charles, and the Aotearoa Jazz Orchestra has its inaugural performance with a Duke Ellington arrangement of Tchaikovsky’s The Nutcracker Suite. Many of the hospitality venues in Courtenay Place and its surrounding streets are planning intimate jazz gigs across the festival. Follow the sound of saxophones to find a spot to park up for the night.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Yoko–Zuna: A Live Tribute to KAYTRANADA tickets, This October, Aotearoa electronic/progressive hip-hop powerhouse Yoko-Zuna will make their long anticipated return to Pōneke, presenting the music of KAYTRANADA in the city's magnificent Meow NUI. Over the past decade Yoko-Zuna have firmly established themselves as one of the country’s most exciting live acts and a favourite on the festival circuit. Just back from a world tour with hip-hop multihyphenate CHAII, the four piece made up of Swap Gomez, J.Y Lee, Kenji Iwamitsu-Holdaway, & Frank Eliesa once again join forces to perform their live tribute to a genre-defying beat wizard.
Louis Kevin Celestin aka KAYTRANADA is a Haitian-Canadian record producer and DJ. He first made waves in 2010 with a steady stream of mixtapes, remixes, and original tracks released under the name Kaytradamus. By 2013, reintroducing himself as KAYTRANADA, he was turning heads across the global music scene. The momentum only grew—by 2014, he landed a deal with the influential label XL Recordings. In 2016, he dropped his debut studio album, 99.9%, which was met with widespread critical acclaim. 2019’s Bubba—a genre-blurring triumph earned him two Grammy Awards, including Best Dance/Electronic Album, solidifying his place as one of the most innovative voices in contemporary music.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Echoes of Us - WJF 2025, Echoes of Us is a live, improvised music experience where you are the muse. In an evening of deep reflection, spontaneous creativity and genuine musicianship, a house band fronted by saxophonist and woodwind doubler Zoe Ioannou, invites you as the audience to share personal moments, memories, or themes—light-hearted, emotional, joyful, tender–anything you desire. These offerings are then to be transformed into rich, evolving soundscapes created in real-time by the musicians. Perfectly set in the warm, intimate and light atmosphere of Whisky and Wood, this event offers an invitation to slow down, listen deeply, and feel heard in a way words alone often cannot achieve. Come as you are—your story may become the music that moves and echoes us all at Wellington Jazz Festival 2025.
Doors open 4.30pm for a 5pm start.
label: Music & Concerts

“The word Prodigy seems to entirely fall short of this soft-spoken young man’s skills, he coaxes sounds and melodies out of his instrument that literally drop jaws.”
The Calgary Herald, CANADA

“Today I saw the future of Folk – Festival goers flocking in the thousands towards the main stage to witness a young musical phenomenon from Australia dish out an absolute show-stopper.” The Firefly Column, USA

“reinventing roots guitar” Rhythms Magazine, AUSTRALIA“Watching Daniel Champagne perform is a once in a lifetime experience. He is a true prodigy that plays like no one else could possibly play unless they spent at least two lifetimes studying the art.” BW Review, NEW ZEALAND

description:
Sir Dave Dobbyn — Selected Songs, He’s a treasured musical voice in New Zealand culture. Sir Dave Dobbyn has over 45 years of experience as a singer, songwriter, and recording artist. For one special night, he will be singing in Wellington at The Opera House. Many of his songs have acted as a backdrop to Kiwis’ lives and shaped the sound of the country’s popular music scene. Some of Dave’s songs are so famous that they have become anthems. You’ll get to hear many of them along with rich pickings from his back catalogue. 
Diagnosed with Parkinson’s Disease in 2022, Dave declared it “business as usual” — and continues to inspire with his unmistakable voice and enduring stage presence. Recognised with a Knighthood in 2021 for his services to music, Dave remains one of New Zealand’s most revered cultural figures.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Big Christmas Spectacular, Is that the sound of Santa’s sleigh? The familiar jingle of bells will be accompanied by live music, dance, and humour at a huge yuletide celebration. The Big Christmas Spectacular makes its Wellington debut at The Opera House in December. What better way to kick start the holiday season than a live show? There will be ballet, contemporary, tap, jazz, and stunning chorus lines. Award-winning musical theatre stars will collaborate with 25 dazzling dancers and live musicians. Together, they’ll transport you to a winter wonderland. 
Christmas jingles, hilarious comedy moments, and world-class show dancing make this perfect for all ages.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Gregory Alan Isakov,   American indie-folk artist Gregory Alan Isakov is a Grammy-nominated singer and songwriter. He’s bringing his intimate and lyric-driven show to Wellington in February. Audiences will be given a special opportunity to experience stripped-down acoustic arrangements. He’ll delve into favourites from six of his full-length studio albums, including his most recent ‘Appaloosa Bones’. 
This 2023 album was praised with an Associated Press reviewer saying, “His new songs are relentlessly majestic, a kind of musical morphine”. Gregory has amassed a devoted community of fans who have helped him garner over 1 billion streams on listening platforms to date.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
The Rock Orchestra by Candlelight, When you think of hard rock and metal, you might not naturally connect them to the refined sounds of classical music. The Rock Orchestra by Candlelight has done just that. After entertaining 700,000 people across the UK, USA and Europe, it’s coming to Wellington. 
Prepare for a spellbinding 90-minute spectacle infusing rock and metal anthems with beautiful orchestral energy. A band of 13 classical musicians will accompany the fiery tunes. Through a wall of distortion, you’ll witness the unexpected union of classical and metal music. 
In an ethereal candlelit setting, you’ll experience the music of famous bands. Hear Metallica, AC/DC, Rage Against the Machine, My Chemical Romance, Linkin' Park, SOAD, Guns N’ Roses, Evanescence, Aerosmith, The Cranberries, and more.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
The Rocky Horror Show, Dust off your corset, strap on your heels, and get ready to Time Warp like it’s 1973. After a 15-year hiatus, The Rocky Horror Show is back. The musical, written 50 years ago by New Zealand national treasure Richard O’Brien, stars a phenomenal West End cast. This high-energy stage spectacular features all the catchy songs you know and love: Sweet Transvestite, Dammit Janet, and the pelvic-thrusting, showstopper Time Warp. 
The show follows two squeaky-clean college kids, Brad and Janet. The couple find themselves stranded outside a mysterious mansion. Inside awaits the fabulous and flamboyant Dr Frank’n’Furter, and a wild adventure full of fun, frolics, frocks, and frivolity. 
The Rocky Horror Show is the longest continuously running contemporary musical in the world. It has thrilled over 35 million theatregoers, been staged in 30 countries, and translated into 20 languages. Get dressed up, let loose, and be your fabulous self at the biggest glitter-soaked party in town.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
KOHA SUNDAY YOGA - Heated Flow, Join us EVERY Sunday for a 90 minute Heated Flow for koha entry (ie, give what you can)! Proceeds are donated to a different charitable organisation each month that's committed to supporting the wellbeing of Aotearoa!
This weekly class is open to everyone, regardless of yoga experience - haere mai!
BYO mat or hire for $2; towels available for $3 and make sure to bring a big water bottle!
To book: Download the AWHI app to view the timetable, or simply show up in good time on Sunday!
WHAT IS 'KOHA'? Koha loosely translates to 'gift' or exchange. In other words, pay what you can for the class!
For more information about our studio, visit our website at awhiyoga.co.nz
label: Sports & Fitness

description:
XTrail Spring - Skyline Scramble, The Skyline trails deliver a signature Wellington run — native bush, panoramic peaks, and rolling ridgelines. All 3 courses begin in the lush surroundings of Otari-Wilton’s Bush, New Zealand’s only native botanic garden, and wind their way up to the summit of Johnston Hill. The short course offers a rewarding climb and scenic descent, while the long course adds a little extra vert and extends your adventure along the iconic Skyline Track, with sweeping views over the city, coast, and beyond. With flowing trails and plenty of natural beauty, it’s a proper taste of Wellington’s wild backyard.
https://barefootxtrail.co.nz/
label: Sports & Fitness

description:
Tip Track Marathon: Cloud 9, START TIMES:
7am - Marathon
9am - Half Marathon
Website: tiptrackmarathon.co.nz
Rego: https://tip-track-marathon.lilregie.com/boo.../attendees/new
COURSE DETAILS:
Tip Track Marathon (TTM) –
Tip Track Marathon is an out-and-back, out-and-back, out-and-back, out-and-back, out-and-back, out-and-back type course that has proven popular with participants. Each of the six laps is slightly over 7km, with around 400m in elevation (2500m in total). Try not to trip on a loose rock while taking in the aromatic smells emanating from the tip. Ignore the gale-force northerly. It makes for a challenging marathon but you can find comfort in the other runners suffering too.
Recommended donation: $40
Half Marathon -
For those that hate themselves but not as much as the marathoners. Same course as above but three laps instead of six,
Recommended donation: $25
Tip Track Marathon (TTM) is a low-key, no frills trail running race that takes place at the Tip Track in Wellington each year - all in the name of charity. TTM is all about hard hills, high-fives, and doing something stupid for the sake of it. There are no prizes. Your workmates will not understand why you did this. It’s not even that fun.
This is a race for those that want a little more from life than the ordinary. Those that question the monotony of their daytime jobs and wonder, "isn't there meant to be more to life than this?" Enter TTM... I mean, you won't find any answers here but those are the people that tend to be attracted to it.
DONATIONS:
All entry fees charged go to our charities for 2025:
Youthline Wellington
Social Supermarket
There is a recommended donation amount for each race of $40 (TTM) or $25 (Half). These are recommended only. If you are not in a position to donate, then give whatever you can, if you earn a bit more then feel free to pop in a bit more.
Previous years we have raised:
2024 - $5,500 for the Social Supermarket and OMF
2023 - $5,125 for the Social Supermarket
2022 - $3,600 split between Trailblazers and Wellington Women's Refuge
2021 - $3,770 split between Trailblazers and Wellington Women's Refuge
2020 - $3,376 split between Challenge 2000 and Wellington Women's Refuge
label: Sports & Fitness

description:
Take A Kid Tramping - Maketawa Hut Overnight, Family tramping.
Take a Kid Tramping Trip for our kids with extra stamina and ability to carry an overnight pack, this one has a lot of climbing. We will head up the translator track from North Egmont, turn off and follow the ridge down to the hut. The next day we will return via the Makatawa track down through the bush and across a few streams.
All participants must be equipped for tramping in alpine conditions. Overnight tramping equipment required.
Children must be accompanied by a parent or caregiver approved by their guardian.
Shared transport costs apply, unless own transport is provided.
$10 per adult passenger, kids or own car free + hut fee.
Hut Tickets or annual pass required.
If interested, please register by Thursday 11 September:
Jo-anne Mowat | takt@nptc.org.nz
label: Sports & Fitness
